summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell. The emails discuss the status of de-designating highly confidential images, arranging review of evidence in Colorado, and resolving technical problems with document production. The government is preparing to produce thousands of images from Epstein's devices and CDs.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell corresponding with prosecutors about discovery issues, including review of images and evidence from Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, copied on discovery correspondence.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on discovery correspondence regarding evidence issues.

connections.description: Correspondence regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell case, with Menninger as defense attorney and Pagliuca as government contractor.
Both are defense attorneys representing Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the same discovery correspondence.

events.title: Scheduled trial date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: Trial date mentioned in correspondence as November 29, 2021.

events.title: FBI Report on Epstein evidence
events.description: FBI report indicating approximately 33,747 highly confidential images and 895 highly confidential videos identified from CART-processed evidence.

keyFacts: The FBI identified approximately 33,747 highly confidential images and 895 highly confidential videos from CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.
The government was preparing to produce thousands of images from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, with approximately 40,000 images previously produced.
Evidence included a 3D scan of Epstein's private island that had production difficulties.
The defense requested to review evidence at the FBI office in Colorado rather than traveling to New York.
The correspondence reveals significant technical problems with document production, including corrupt files, unviewable images, and metadata issues.
